sub_title: PhD candidate at MERLN Institute for Technology-Inspired Regenerative Medicine
summary:
I concluded my Integrated Master’s Degree in Bioengineering at the University of Porto (Portugal) in 2018. I performed my MSc thesis project at i3S/INEB in Porto and the central aim was to engineer a 3D tumor microenvironment to study the crosstalk between cells undergoing epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition and vascular cells. A heterotypic 3D breast cancer model was established based on a vascularized porous scaffold combined with an epithelial cell-laden hydrogel. After my graduation, I worked as a research fellow in Prof. João Mano Lab at the University of Aveiro (Portugal). My work was focused on the development of spherically structured 3D pancreatic-stromal heterotypic tumor models for combinatorial drug screening.

In September 2020, I joined MERLN as a Doctoral candidate. My PhD project is part of a European project called JOINTPROMISE that aims to develop an automated, GMP-grade platform producing large, patterned and vascularized joint implants providing also a paradigm shift for generic automated manufacturing of organoid-based tissue implants. The main challenge to engineer osteochondral tissue is to mimic their complex structural organization and functionality. My goal is to implement bioprinting approaches for the creation of a stable and transient chondral microtissues to be incorporated in the aimed implants.

school.name: Faculdade de Engenharia da Universidade do Porto
Universidade de Trás-os-Montes e Alto Douro

profile_positions.description: Department of Complex Tissue Regeneration at MERLN Institute for Technology-Inspired Regenerative Medicine, Maastricht University under the Faculty of Health, Medicine and Life Sciences (FHML) and University Medical Center (UMC+)
profile_positions.title: PhD candidate

profile_positions.description:
Project:
PANGEIA - Production of 3D+ microcapsule platforms for large-scale laboratory evaluation of novel combinatorial therapies for pancreatic cancer. 
My work was focused on the development of spherically structured 3D pancreatic-stromal heterotypic tumor models for combinatorial drug screening. I was able to develop a biomimetic 3D model consisting of co-cultured Human pancreatic cancer cells (PANC-1) and Pancreatic stellate cancer associated fibroblasts (CAFs), which self-assembled into a heterotypic multicellular 3D tumor spheroid in vitro.
This project was developed at CICECO – Aveiro Institute of Materials, University of Aveiro, under the scientific supervision of Dr. Vítor Gaspar and Prof. Dr. João Mano.
profile_positions.title: Research Fellow

company.name: i3S - Instituto de Investigação e Inovação em Saúde

profile_positions.description:
Master student at Bioengineered 3D Microenvironments group under the supervision of Dr. Sílvia Bidarra and Prof. Cristina Barrias.
During my master thesis I participated in a project called 3DEMT – “A 3D microarray platform for the high-throughput analysis of the role of the extracellular matrix in cancer-associated epithelial-to-mesenchymal transitions”, financed by FCT (PTDC/BBB-ECT/2518/2014). The central aim was to engineer a 3D tumor microenvironment to study the crosstalk between cells undergoing epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition and vascular cells. A heterotypic 3D breast cancer model was established based on a vascularized porous scaffold combined with an epithelial cell-laden hydrogel.

profile_positions.description: Research Trainee at Bioengineered 3D Microenvironments group under the supervision of Dr Sílvia Bidarra and co-supervised by Dr Cristina Barrias.
profile_positions.title: Research Trainee

profile_positions.description:
Research intern in the Department of Biomedical Engineering, University of Groningen, University Medical Center Groningen, Groningen, The Netherlands.
Supervisors: Dr. Patrick van Rijn and Dr. Philipp T. Kühn
Research project: Light-triggered and bio-engineered anti-microbial hydrogels
Under Erasmus+ programme, I worked as a research intern in the University Medical Centrum Groningen and University of Groningen (Netherlands), where I focused on the development of light-triggered and bio-engineered anti-microbial hydrogels, under the supervision of Dr. Patrick van Rijn. I studied the possibility of using cyclodextrin modified alginate hydrogels as a delivery tool for the newly photo-switchable antibiotics developed by Wiktor Szimanski and Ben Feringa. I studied the photo-responsive system using UV-Vis, IR, NMR and used peptide chemistry for the hydrogel development.
profile_positions.title: Research Intern
